title: Externals shouldn't expand aliases
body:
# Description

For some reason, not sure why, externals had their own alias expansion logic in the parser. In case where you were expanding to an alias with the same name, you'd loop forever. This removes the secondary expansion logic, leaving the primary one only.

fixes #4888

# Tests

Make sure you've run and fixed any issues with these commands:

# Description

This covers most edge cases that I could come up with to count lines.

Currently will not work with `"one(char nl)two" | size` just as `"one(char nl)two" | lines` doesn't. If someone wants to submit a PR to `lines` and `size` to add this enhancement, we'll probably accept it.

title: Add `export alias` and `export extern`
body:
# Description

This adds two more forms of export: `export alias` and `export extern`. The alias form allows you to create aliases and define them in a module, importing them as necessary.

`export extern` is similar - you can define an extern which can later be imported. This also helps keep custom completion functions in the module outside of the current scope, while still allowing you to import the extern and get the custom completion benefits.

eg)
```
module foo {
  export extern cat [fname: string@bozo];
  def bozo [] { [abc, def] }
}

# then, to use it:

use foo cat
cat <tab> # gets custom completions, but `bozo` is not in scope here

# or:

use foo *
cat <tab>
```

# Tests

Make sure you've run and fixed any issues with these commands:

- [x] `cargo fmt --all -- --check` to check standard code formatting (`cargo fmt --all` applies these changes)
- [x] `cargo clippy --all --all-features -- -D warnings -D clippy::unwrap_used -A clippy::needless_collect` to check that you're using the standard code style
- [x] `cargo build; cargo test --all --all-features` to check that all the tests pass

title: Add an alias denylist for expansions
body:
# Description

This threads an alias denylist through most of the parser. This should help us more accurately deny expansion while also allowing hiding of the same aliases. While I was working on this, I think this also corrects a fair number of subtle hiding bugs where we should have been checking a denylist in more places but weren't.

Fixes #4868 

# Tests

title: rename `update` to `upsert` to mirror what it really does
body:
# Description

This PR renames the `update` command to `upsert` to mirror what it really does, which is update an item if it exists and if it does not exist, insert it.

`upsert` is a command term used in many databases including PostgreSQL, Sqlite, MySql, Oracle, and others.

----
This got a little more complicated. This happens to be the first PR _after_ the latest `reedline` was published. So, I had to update to the latest `reedline` which means I also had to update to the latest `nu-ansi-term`.

# Tests

Make sure you've run and fixed any issues with these commands:

- [x] `cargo fmt --all -- --check` to check standard code formatting (`cargo fmt --all` applies these changes)
- [x] `cargo clippy --all --all-features -- -D warnings -D clippy::unwrap_used -A clippy::needless_collect` to check that you're using the standard code style
- [x] `cargo build; cargo test --all --all-features` to check that all the tests pass

title: Allow expanding aliases before keywords, improve hiding
body:
# Description

@kubouch - can you take a look to see if this does what you need?

This should in theory fix https://github.com/nushell/nushell/issues/4839

I had to remove the warnings for double hiding as it was tricky to get things to work both at parse time and eval time. Once it's hidden at parse time, we don't know it was already hidden at eval time and don't know when to give an error. Likewise, at parse time, we don't know if it's intended to be an env var hiding.

I removed the logic that removes the definitions/aliases from the working set and just used the visibility logic. Updated both def/alias for this. I added a test that works like the one in #4839 

# Tests

Make sure you've run and fixed any issues with these commands:

- [x] `cargo build; cargo test --all --all-features` to check that all the tests pass

title: Change update help+examples for creating new columns
body:
# Description

`update` has taken over `insert`'s duties (it can now create columns instead of just changing existing ones). Adjusting the help+examples to reflect that.

# Notes

FWIW I find the new behavior unintuitive and error-prone (easy to accidentally create a new column when you want to update an existing one). Might be worth revisiting in the future?

I initially tried enabling example tests for `update`, but one of the existing examples fails with an `ExternalNotSupported` error:

```
input: echo [[project, authors]; ['nu', ['Andrés', 'JT', 'Yehuda']]] | update authors { get authors | str collect ',' }
result: List { vals: [Error { error: ExternalNotSupported(Span { start: 260, end: 263 }) }], span: Span { start: 0, end: 0 } }
```

# Tests

Make sure you've run and fixed any issues with these commands:

- [x] `cargo fmt --all -- --check` to check standard code formatting (`cargo fmt --all` applies these changes)
- [x] `cargo clippy --all --all-features -- -D warnings -D clippy::unwrap_used -A clippy::needless_collect` to check that you're using the standard code style
- [x] `cargo build; cargo test --all --all-features` to check that all the tests pass

title: Move repl loop and command/script execution to nu_cli
body:
# Description

Within Couchbase Shell we need to be able to start the Nushell repl and execute scripts/files. By moving that functionality to nu_cli, this enables us to do so without duplicating a load of code. This moving could likely be more nuanced, there's a lot that has had to move here.

title: Streaming support for lines with raw streams
body:
# Description

This adds streaming support for the `lines` command when used with an external (so removes blocking)

I'd been using `lines` to chop while tailing structured (json) aws logs and combined with `each` & `from json` (and now with `print`) found it great to be able to highlight/reformat them live with nushell goodness, but noticed it blocking since 0.59.

This covers the requirements of the current tests and my uses, I'm not sure if Value::Binary needs to be covered or if moving away from `input.collect_string("", &config)?;` was a bad idea, or just easier/better ways to implement this...

Thanks for the great work all. 

# Tests

Make sure you've run and fixed any issues with these commands:

- [x] `cargo fmt --all -- --check` to check standard code formatting (`cargo fmt --all` applies these changes)
- [x] `cargo clippy --all --all-features -- -D warnings -D clippy::unwrap_used -A clippy::needless_collect` to check that you're using the standard code style
- [x] `cargo build; cargo test --all --all-features` to check that all the tests pass

title: Nu glob
body:
# Description

This PR does two unrelated things:

* forks the `glob` crate to remove the `[]` syntax that is causing problems with users expecting more traditional globs.
* Normalises the license holder name across licenses. We were using different names in different areas, so all licenses mention the same entity name

# Tests

- [x] `cargo fmt --all -- --check` to check standard code formatting (`cargo fmt --all` applies these changes)

fixes https://github.com/nushell/nushell/issues/4475

title: Make `reduce -n` more sensible
body:
# Description

This slightly changes the semantics for `reduce -n`. Now, we don't add the index to the `$acc` on the way out if we're in numbered mode. This is so that the `$acc` variable keeps the same type through the process, which is a bit easier to read and is more predictable.

I also went ahead and made errors during reduction immediate bubble up and added `ctrlc` protection to the reduction.

fixes #4759 

# Tests

Make sure you've run and fixed any issues with these commands:

- [x] `cargo fmt --all -- --check` to check standard code formatting (`cargo fmt --all` applies these changes)

- [x] `cargo build; cargo test --all --all-features` to check that all the tests pass

title: Adds support for default values to params and flags
body:
# Description

This allows you to add default values to your positional parameters and flags:

```
> def foo [x = 10] { $x }
```

```
> def foo [--x = 100] { $x }
```

These default values are checked against the specified type to make sure they match. Default values also set the type of the parameter.

# Tests

title: Fix rest parsing
Add serialization for JSON and form bodies in `post`
body:
# Description

Allows for passing JSON payloads and form data in the shape of a `record` or a list of key value pairs (only for forms to allow duplicates). Existing behaviour is preserved as it previously only accepted strings or binary data and it parses `--content-type` to distinguish between JSON and form bodies.

# Examples

```
post -t application/json url.com { test: abcd }
post -t application/x-www-form-urlencoded [ test abcd test efgh ]
```

# Tests

title: Simplify group/window into their own commands
body:
# Description

(Idea from adamijak on discord)

Instead of having `each group`, `each window`, `par-each group` and more, split the grouping or windowing into their own command, allowing for more flexible mixing of that with `each`, `par-each` or other iterators.

Before:

```
> ls | each group 3 { |$it| $it }
```

Now:

```
> ls | group 3
```

And likewise for `window`.

# Tests

Make sure you've run and fixed any issues with these commands:

- [x] `cargo fmt --all -- --check` to check standard code formatting (`cargo fmt --all` applies these changes)

- [x] `cargo build; cargo test --all --all-features` to check that all the tests pass

title: Do not pass non-string env vars to externals
body:
# Description

Environment variables that are not a string and don't have `to_string` env conversion will not be passed to externals. Previously, the env variables were forced to be strings which caused some useless or subtly broken conversions:
* PATH list would become `[/some/path1:/some/path2:/some/path3]`
* Blocks would become `<Block XYZ>`
* Boolean `true` would become `"true"` string

These values will now be internal within Nushell. You'd need to explicitly add `to_string` to `ENV_CONVERSIONS` to export them.

You can see which env. vars are Nushell-only by `env | where raw == $nothing`.

# Tests

Make sure you've run and fixed any issues with these commands:

- [x] `cargo fmt --all -- --check` to check standard code formatting (`cargo fmt --all` applies these changes)
- [x] `cargo clippy --all --all-features -- -D warnings -D clippy::unwrap_used -A clippy::needless_collect` to check that you're using the standard code style
- [x] `cargo build; cargo test --all --all-features` to check that all the tests pass

# Description

This adds back the `--append` flag to save that was there before engine-q. Also adds a test case to ensure it actually appends.

# Tests

Make sure you've run and fixed any issues with these commands:

- [x] `cargo fmt --all -- --check` to check standard code formatting (`cargo fmt --all` applies these changes)
- [x] `cargo clippy --all --all-features -- -D warnings -D clippy::unwrap_used -A clippy::needless_collect` to check that you're using the standard code style
- [x] `cargo build; cargo test --all --all-features` to check that all the tests pass

title: Allow save to accept a list of strings
body:
# Description

Save now accepts a list of strings and will treat it as a list of lines.

# Tests

Make sure you've run and fixed any issues with these commands:

- [x] `cargo fmt --all -- --check` to check standard code formatting (`cargo fmt --all` applies these changes)
- [x] `cargo clippy --all --all-features -- -D warnings -D clippy::unwrap_used -A clippy::needless_collect` to check that you're using the standard code style
- [x] `cargo build; cargo test --all --all-features` to check that all the tests pass

title: Add more multiline pipeline forms
body:
# Description

This allows three ways for a pipeline to be written:

```
all | on | one | line
```

And in multilines:
```
with |
ending |
pipes
```

And, now in scripts, you can use:

```
with
| starting
| pipes
```

We currently require the pipeline not be separated by more than one line for the parser to understand that it's all coming from one pipeline.

fixes https://github.com/nushell/nushell/issues/4059

# Tests

Make sure you've run and fixed any issues with these commands:

- [x] `cargo fmt --all -- --check` to check standard code formatting (`cargo fmt --all` applies these changes)
- [x] `cargo clippy --all --all-features -- -D warnings -D clippy::unwrap_used -A clippy::needless_collect` to check that you're using the standard code style
- [x] `cargo build; cargo test --all --all-features` to check that all the tests pass

title: remove the hard coded escaping from split row and split column
body:
# Description

I had a hard time splitting text line "one\ntwo\nthree" when it was in a file. Turns out there were some hard-coded escaping going on under the hood. This PR removes that.

# Tests

Make sure you've run and fixed any issues with these commands:

- [x] `cargo fmt --all -- --check` to check standard code formatting (`cargo fmt --all` applies these changes)
